questions.question_text:
You manage a project by using Azure Board, and you manage the project code by using Azure Repos.

You have a bug work item that has an ID of 123.

You need to set the work item state to Resolved.

What should you add to the commit message?

You manage a project by using Azure Boards, and you manage the project code by using GitHub repositories.

You have a work item that has an ID of 123.

You need to link a commit message in GitHub to work item 123 on the board.

What are two ways to achieve the goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.D: From the Links settings of work item 123, select Add link, select Existing item, and then enter the URL of the commit.
choices.E: To work item 123, add a comment that includes the URL of the commit.
choices.C: Add GH-123 to the text of the commit message.
choices.B: Add AB#123 to the text of the commit message.
choices.A: From the Development settings of work item 123, select Add link, and then enter the URL of the commit.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A instead of D since the Links settings is specifically for task dependencies, like parent-child relationships, related work, etc.
Development section literally has a link for Commits.

Open a User Story or task in DevOps and you will see.

Selected Answer: BD
B: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops#use-ab-to-link-from-github-to-azure-boards-work-items

D: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops#add-work-item-link-to-github-branch-commit-or-pull-request

Selected Answer: AB
When I open my work item, I can see "add link" under the Development section. Here I can add a GitHub commit URL. "Search for GitHub Commits is performed only over the default branch. To link a commit outside of the default branch, you have to paste its URL manually."

Option A is not correct because the Development section in Azure Boards does not provide a direct way to add a link to a commit by entering its URL. Instead, linking commits to work items is typically done through the commit message itself or through the Links settings.

Using AB#123 in the commit message (Option B) is a straightforward way to automatically link the commit to the work item.
Correct answer BD
The answer is "NO", because the event should be when code is pushed and not when a build is completed.
Got this question in Feb-2022 exam. Answer is : Code Push event.

Selected Answer: B
Agree with answer

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer

Selected Answer: B
On exam 2023-09-06, selected B. No

Selected Answer: B
B. No

Explanation:

The "build completed" event in Azure DevOps is triggered when a build pipeline run is completed, not when a developer commits changes to a branch in Azure Repos.

To achieve the goal of sending a notification to Jenkins when a developer commits changes to a branch in Azure Repos, a service hook subscription needs to be created that uses the code push event or the pull request created event.

Therefore, creating a service hook subscription that uses the "build completed" event would not meet the goal.

Well, this depends on how "lax" Microsoft sees the "commit" action. If it's just a commit done locally, on some random branch, it will not trigger Jenkins. If you push your code to origin or prepare PR, that will trigger Jenkins. Here is ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/overview?view=azure-devops
The answer is NO. You can read up on the same from the below link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/overview?view=azure-devops

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/services/jenkins?view=azure-devops:

"You can trigger a Jenkins build when you push code to your project's Git repository"

Answer is No

Selected Answer: B
correct answer

Question is - You need Azure DevOps to send a notification to Jenkins when a developer commits changes to a branch in Azure Repos.
- Clearly scenario is Code pushed not build completed so answer should be No
as given solution says - You create a service hook subscription that uses the build completed event.
Given answer is correct as it is for branch

In addition to that the code pushed event available in the trigger type, please refer the below link for more info,
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/services/jenkins?view=azure-devops

The answer is "Yes". If you want to confirm, please refer the below link,
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/services/jenkins?view=azure-devops

If there is any changes in the code repo, the service hooks can be triggered for Java/any app.

Doing a commit is not equal to doing a push, the documentation says "You can trigger a Jenkins build when you push code to your project's Git repository", that's it pushing your code into Git, not just committing your code
The answer is "yes". There is a service hook with push code type of event as in the documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/service-hooks/services/jenkins?view=azure-devops

comments.content: But the description also says that the event should be "code pushed", not "build completed", so that's why the answer is "No".
I agree , the answer is NO

discussion.content: Answer is Yes, the description is right!

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You integrate a cloud-hosted Jenkins server and a new Azure DevOps deployment.
You need Azure DevOps to send a notification to Jenkins when a developer commits changes to a branch in Azure Repos.
Solution: You create a service hook subscription that uses the build completed event.
Does this meet the goal?

choices.A: Create a GitHub personal access token (PAT).
choices.D: Select Allow anonymous users to access the status badge.
choices.B: Enable GitHub annotations for the board.
choices.C: Install the Azure Boards app for GitHub.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The question asks, "What should you do first?" I think you need to install the Azure Boards app first.

Selected Answer: C
C which is needed for the integration to occur

D. Select Allow anonymous users to access the status badge. This relates to badge visibility but isn't the primary step to get the integration working.

Selected Answer: C
C. Install the Azure Boards app for GitHub.

Selected Answer: C
C. Install the Azure Boards app for GitHub.

Selected Answer: D
I would pick D. It's the easiest option to provide a badge in the README
which links to the board. This can be done with minimal effort. The documentation also states that anonymous access must be allowed. 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/configure-status-badges?view=azure-devops#add-a-status-badge

Given answer is correct : Install the Azure Boards app for GitHub.
The Azure Boards app for GitHub allows you to link GitHub commits and pull requests to your Azure Boards work items. Therefore, when the status of a work item on the Azure Boards changes, this change will reflect on the README.md file on GitHub.

You have a project in Azure DevOps that uses an Azure Boards board and stores code in a GitHub repository. The repository contains a file named README.md.

You need to ensure that README.md includes the status of the work items on the board. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you do first?

You have a bug work item that has an ID of 123.

You need to set the work item state to Resolved.

What should you add to the commit message?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Nevermind, going with D since that keyword does exist.

Supported Keywords for Commit Messages
These keywords can be used to link a commit to a work item and/or update its state:

To Resolve or Close a Work Item (Sets the State to Resolved or Closed):
Resolves
Resolve
Resolved
Fixes
Fix
Fixed
Closes
Close
Closed
